generalProcedures.text: The San Angelo District Office must be given a minimum of four hours notice prior to setting any plugs  (325) 657-7450.

The operator of a well must have a representative on location during the setting of all plugs.  The operator's representative cannot be an employee of the plugging contractor unless the contractor and the operator are the same entity.

All water flows, loss circulation, holes in pipe, gas pressure, well control, hydrogen sulfide, and junked hole problems should immediately be brought to the attention of the Railroad Commission’s District Office.

The well must be circulated with mud prior to setting plugs.  The mud must have a minimum weight of 9.5 lbs./gal. and a  funnel viscosity of at least 40 seconds.  The well should be in a static condition before cement is pumped.

The cementing contractor must have an active Organization Report and be on the Commission’s Approved Cementer’s List.   Revisions to Statewide Rule 3.14 effective December 28, 1999, allow for the operator and  plugging contractor to be held responsible for the proper plugging of a well.

All cement plugs must be pumped through tubing or drill pipe (casing is not allowed).  When casing is not recovered, the casing must be perforated and cement pumped under a packer of cement retainer.  The casing should be pressure tested prior to perforating.

Class C cement must be used for all plugs.    The cement must meet API specifications for cement commonly used in West Texas for normal oilfield applications, and  the cement should be “neat” cement with no fillers or additives. Class C should have a slurry weight of 14.8 Lbs./Gal  and Class H 16.4 Lbs./Gal.

Plugs placed across the base of usable quality water, across the surface casing shoe, above the Coleman Junction and                 San Andres, and above perforations that were used to produce out of or inject into must be tagged.
All cast iron bridge plugs must have a minimum of 20’ of cement on top of the plug in order to be considered a proper plug.

Pits must be emptied immediately.  Revisions to SWR 3.14 effective December 28, 1999, require that pits be backfilled and piping, vessels, tanks, equipment, loose junk and trash be removed from a plugged well within 120 days of  the time plugging operations are completed.
No permanent dry hole caps or welded plates may be left on a well after plugging operations are completed.

coke.name: Coke County
notes: Please see the attached plugging chart for the number of sacks in each plug.
We need a plug (CIBP plus 20 FT. cement or a cement plug) above the perfs; the bottom of
the plug should be roughly 50 FT. above the perfs.  We also need a plug placed
immediately above each formation listed.  If the field in question is not present, please either
use known tops in the subject field or the tops in a listed nearby field.  In addition, we need
a plug placed 50 FT. below the shoe of the surface casing to 50 FT. above the shoe.
If the surface casing has been set deeper than 200 FT. below the base of the deepest
usable quality water stratum, an additional 100 FT. cement plug must be placed inside
